Event: Egyptian calendar
Bronze Age begins in the Near East[1]
Newgrange Ireland
Hakra Phase of the Indus Valley Civilization begins in the Indian Sub-continent.
Saflieni phase in Maltese prehistory
Cycladic civilization in Greece
Norte Chico civilization begins in Peru
Rise of Proto-Elamite Civilization in Iran
Skara Brae Scotland
First dynasty of Egypt
Sumerian cuneiform writing system.[2]
Stonehenge construction begins. In its first version, it consisted of a circular ditch and bank, with 56 wooden posts.[3]
Cucuteni-Trypillian culture in Romania and the Ukraine
Jiroft civilization begins in Iran
First known use of papyrus by Egyptians
Kot Diji phase of the Indus Valley Civilization begins
Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors period in China
Minoan Civilization ancient palace city Knossos reach 80,000 inhabitants
Rise of Elam in Iran
The Old Kingdom begins in Egypt
Oldest known surviving literature: Sumerian texts from Abu Salabikh, including the Instructions of Shuruppak and the Kesh temple hymn.
Mature Harappan phase of the Indus Valley civilization (in present-day Pakistan and India) begins
Emergence of Maya culture in the Yucatï¿½n Peninsula
King Khufu completes the Great Pyramid of Giza.
The mammoth goes extinct.

4.2 kiloyear event: a severe aridification phase, likely connected to a Bond event, which was registered throughout most North Africa, Middle East and continental North America. Related droughts very likely caused the collapse of the Old Kingdom in Egypt and of the Akkadian Empire in Mesopotamia.
completion of Stonehenge.
Yu the Great established the Xia Dynasty in China
Domestication of the horse
alphabetic writing emerges
Indus Valley Civilization comes to an end but is continued by the Cemetery H culture; The beginning of Poverty Point Civilization in North America
Minoan civilization on Crete is destroyed by the Minoan eruption of Santorini island.
Mycenaean Greece
The beginning of Shang Dynasty in China, evidence of a fully developed Chinese writing system
Beginning of Hittite dominance of the Eastern Mediterranean region
Composition of the Rigveda is completed
Olmec civilization flourishes in Pre-Columbian Mexico, during Mesoamerica's Formative period
The Hallstatt culture

Bronze Age collapse in Southwestern Asia and in the Eastern Mediterranean region. This period is also the setting of the Iliad and the Odyssey epic poems (which were composed about four centuries later).
Disintegration of Hittite Empire
Use of Iron spreads.
The Zhou force (led by King Wu of Zhou) overthrow the last king of Shang Dynasty; Zhou Dynasty established in China
The beginning of the Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy) occurred sometime between these dates
Approximate date for the composition of the Iliad and the Odyssey
Rise of Greek city-states
First recorded Olympic Games.
Founding of Rome (traditional date)
Tiglath-Pileser III becomes the new king of Assyria. With time he conquers neighboring countries and turns Assyria into an empire.
Rise of the Median Empire.
Spring and Autumn Period begins in China; Zhou Dynasty's power is diminishing; the era of the Hundred Schools of Thought.
the construction of Marib Dam in Arabia Felix.
purported date of the accession of Jimmu, the mythical first Emperor of Japan.
Rise of Persian Empire.
An alliance between the Babylonians, Medes, and Scythians succeeds in destroying Nineveh and causing subsequent fall of the Assyrian empire.
Sixteen Maha Janapadas ("Great Realms" or "Great Kingdoms") emerge in India.
Evidence of writing system appear in Oaxaca used by the Zapotec civilization.
Pandyan kingdom in South India.
Destruction of the First Temple in Jerusalem (Solomon's Temple) by the Babylonians.
Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha), founder of Buddhism is born as a prince of the Shakya tribe, which ruled parts of Magadha, one of the Maha Janapadas.
Confucius, founder of Confucianism, is born.
Foundation of the Persian Empire by Cyrus the Great.
Mahavira, founder of Jainism is born.
Cyrus the Great overthrows Croesus King of Lydia.
Rise of Magadha as the dominant power under Bimbisara.
The Fall of the Babylonian Empire and liberation of the Jews by Cyrus the Great.
Death of Cyrus
Cambyses II of Persia conquers Egypt.
Darius I (Darius the Great) of Persia, subjugates eastern Thrace, Macedonia submits voluntarily, and annexes Libya, Persian Empire at largest extent.
Expulsion of the last King of Rome, founding of Roman Republic (traditional date).
Democracy instituted at Athens
completion of Euclid's Elements
Panini standardizes the grammar and morphology of Sanskrit in the text Ashtadhyayi. Panini's standardized Sanskrit is known as Classical Sanskrit
Pingala uses zero and binary numeral system
King Aristagoras of Miletus incites all of Hellenic Asia Minor to rebel against the Persian Empire, beginning the Greco-Persian Wars.
Greek city-states defeat Persian invasion at Battle of Marathon
Death of Gautama Buddha
Persian invasion of Greece by Xerxes; Battles of Thermopylae and Salamis
Death of Confucius
Warring States period begins in China as the Zhou king became a mere figurehead; China is annexed by regional warlords
Birth of Socrates
Murder of Xerxes
The Oresteia by Aeschylus, the only surviving trilogy of ancient Greek plays, is performed.
The Greco-Persian Wars end.
Building of the Parthenon at Athens started
Construction of the Parthenon is completed
Beginning of the Peloponnesian war between the Greek city-states
Sophocles's play Oedipus the King is first performed
Birth of Plato
Nanda dynasty comes to power.
End of the Peloponnesian War
Zapotec culture flourishes around city of Monte Albï¿½n
Death of Socrates
Birth of Aristotle
Alexander the Great defeats Darius III of Persia in the Battle of Gaugamela, completing his conquest of Persia.
Alexander the Great defeats Indian king Porus in the Battle of the Hydaspes River.
Death of Alexander the Great at Babylon.
Chandragupta Maurya overthrows the Nanda Dynasty of Magadha.

Chandragupta Maurya seizes the satrapies of Paropanisadai (Kabul), Aria (Herat), Arachosia (Qanadahar) and Gedrosia (Baluchistan)from Seleucus I Nicator, the Macedonian satrap of Babylonia, in return for 500 elephants.
Construction of the world's largest pyramid, the Great Pyramid of Cholula, begins in Cholula, Puebla, Mexico.
Ashoka the Great becomes the emperor of the Mauryan Empire
Th_c Dynasty takes over Vi_t Nam (then Kingdom of ï¿½u L_c)
Rise of Parthia (Ashkï¿½niï¿½n), the second native dynasty of ancient Persia
Death of Emperor Ashoka the Great; Decline of the Mauryan Empire
Emergence of Satavahanas in South India
Qin Shi Huang unifies China, end of Warring States period; marking the beginning of Imperial rule in China which lasts until 1912. Construction of the Great Wall by the Qin Dynasty begins.
Kingdom of Nan Yueh extends from North Vi_t Nam to Canton.
Han Dynasty established in China, after the death of Qin Shi Huang; China in this period officially becomes a Confucian state and opens trading connections with the West, i.e. the Silk Road.
Scipio Africanus defeats Hannibal at Battle of Zama.
El Mirador, largest early Maya city, flourishes.
Chera dynasty in South India.
Sunga Empire founded.
Third Punic War between Rome and Carthage. War ends with the complete destruction of Carthage, allowing Rome to conquer modern day Tunisia and Libya.
Roman conquest of Greece, see Roman Greece
Roman conquest of Turkey.
Roman armies enter Gaul for the first time.
First Chinese domination of Vi_t Nam in the form of the Nanyue Kingdom.
Chola dynasty rises in prominence.
The city of Florence is founded.
Roman Civil War between Julius Caesar and Pompey the Great.
Julius Caesar murdered by Marcus Brutus and others; End of Roman Republic; beginning of Roman Empire.
Roman conquest of Egypt.
Three Kingdoms period begins in Korea.
Earliest theorized date for birth of Jesus of Nazareth.
Widely accepted date (Ussher) for birth of Jesus Christ.
Battle of the Teutoburg Forest, the Imperial Roman Army's bloodiest defeat.
Death of Emperor Augustus (Octavian), ascension of his son Tiberius to the throne.
The temple of Jerusalem is reconstructed.
Crucifixion of Jesus Christ, exact date unknown.
Death of Emperor Tiberius, ascension of his nephew Caligula to the throne.
Rome conquers Morocco.
Emperor Caligula is assassinated by the Roman senate. His uncle Claudius succeeds him.
Rome enters Britain for the first time.
Emperor Claudius dies and is succeeded by his grand nephew Nero.
Emperor Nero commits suicide, prompting the Year of the four emperors in Rome.
Destruction of Jerusalem by the armies of Titus.
Destruction of Pompeii by the volcano Vesuvius.
After a two-year rule, Emperor Nerva dies of natural causes, his adopted son Trajan succeeds him.
Roman Empire at largest extent under Emperor Trajan after having conquered modern-day Romania, Iraq and Armenia.
Trajan dies of natural causes. His adopted son Hadrian succeeds him. Hadrian pulls out of Iraq and Armenia.
Hadrian completes the Pantheon in Rome.
Hadrian dies of natural causes. His adopted son Antoninus Pius succeeds him.
Death of Antoninus Pius. His rule was the only one in which Rome did not fight in a war.
Kingdom of Champa in Central Vi_t Nam.
The Buddhist Srivijaya Empire established in Maritime Southeast Asia.
Three Kingdoms period begins in China after the fall of Han Dynasty.
Fall of the Parthian Empire and Rise of the Sassanian Empire.
Defeat of Gordian III (238ï¿½244), Philip the Arab (244ï¿½249), and Valerian (253ï¿½260), by Shapur I of Persia, (Valerian was captured by the Persians).
Emperor Wu established Jin Dynasty providing a temporary unity of China after the devastating Three Kingdoms period.
Diocletian becomes emperor of Rome and splits the Roman Empire into Eastern and Western Empires.
Diocletian begins a large-scale persecution of Christians.
The capital of the Roman empire is officially moved from Rome to Mediolanum (modern day Milan).
Edict of Milan declared that the Roman Empire would tolerate all forms of religious worship.
Constantine I organizes the First Council of Nicaea.
Constantinople is officially named and becomes the capital of the eastern Roman Empire.
Samudragupta becomes the emperor of the Gupta empire.
Emperor Constantine I dies, leaving his sons Constantius II, Constans I, and Constantine II as the emperors of the Roman empire.
Constantius II is left sole emperor with the death of his two brothers.
Birth of Augustine of Hippo
Constantius II dies, his cousin Julian succeeds him.
Battle of Adrianople, Roman army is defeated by the Germanic tribes.
Roman Emperor Theodosius I declares the Arian faith of Christianity heretical.
Theodosius I outlaws all religions other than Catholic Christianity.
Romans are expelled from Britain.
Visigoths and other Germanic tribes cross into Roman-Gaul for the first time.
Visigoths sacks Rome for the first time since 390 BC.
Germanic tribes enter Spain.
Vandals enter North Africa from Spain for the first time
Vandals have conquered the land stretching from Morocco to Tunisia by this time.
Vandals sack Rome, capture Sicily and Sardinia.
Skandagupta repels an Indo-Hephthalite attack on India.

Romulus Augustus, last Western Roman Emperor is forced to abdicate by Odoacer, a chieftain of the Germanic Heruli; Odoacer returns the imperial regalia to Eastern Roman Emperor Zeno in Constantinople in return for the title of dux of Italy; most frequently cited date for the end of ancient history.
